greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of self-conjugate partitions of n having Durfee square of size k (n>=1; 1<=k<=floor(sqrt(n))).
comment: Row n contains floor(sqrt(n)) terms (0's are possible even at the end of the rows). Row sums yield A000700. Sum_{k=1..floor(sqrt(n))} k*T(n,k) = A079499(n).
Also, number of partitions of n into k distinct odd parts. Example: T(13,3)=2 because we have [9,3,1] and [7,5,1]. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 24 2006
reference: G. E. Andrews, The Theory of Partitions, Addison-Wesley, 1976 (pp. 27-28).
G. E. Andrews and K. Eriksson, Integer Partitions, Cambridge Univ. Press, 2004 (pp. 75-78).
formula: T(n, k) = T(n-2*k, k) + T(n-2*k+1, k-1). If n+k is even, T(n, k) = A008284((n-k^2)/2 + k, k) = A072233((n-k^2)/2, k); 0 otherwise. - _Álvar Ibeas_, Jul 27 2020
example: T(13,3)=2 because we have [5,3,3,1,1] and [4,4,3,2] (there is one more self-conjugate partition of 13, namely [7,1,1,1,1,1,1], having Durfee square of size 1).
maple: g:=sum(t^k*q^(k^2)/product(1-q^(2*i),i=1..k),k=1..15): gser:=simplify(series(g,q=0,40)): for n from 1 to 33 do P[n]:=coeff(gser,q^n) od: for n from 1 to 33 do row[n]:=seq(coeff(P[n],t^j),j=1..floor(sqrt(n))) od; # yields sequence in triangular form
mathematica: rows = 31; jmax = Floor[Sqrt[rows]]; T[n_, k_] := SeriesCoefficient[Sum[ t^j*x^(j^2)/Product[1-x^(2i), {i, 1, j}], {j, 1, jmax}], {x, 0, n}, {t, 0, k}]; Table[T[n, k], {n, 1, rows}, {k, 1, Floor[Sqrt[n]]}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 16 2017 *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 14 2006
